Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged
left a bunch of comments.  Lots of generalized safety issues that need resolved.
Please use flat map.
Done
this should be weak_from_this() to handle destruction properly.
Done
same here.
Done
Isn't this now going to duplicate the data?  If we're moving to per-session sockets, we shouldn't be looping over all connections.

I have not moved to per session socket. I am still using single socket per console path. I am worried that someone can exploit it by creating lot of sessions for single console and we will console lot of memory for input and output buffer. What do you think?

> I have not moved to per session socket. I am still using single socket per console path.

We talked about not doing this.....  It is essentially duplicating obmc-console-server.  did something change?

> I am worried that someone can exploit it by creating lot of sessions for single console and we will console lot of memory for input and output buffer.

If they have access to the host console, they can do far worse in easier ways.  Also, what you're describing is prevented with a simple size() check to limit the number of concurrent sessions (like we do in the other websocket handlers).
Done
ok, done.
This doesn't look used anymore?
It is used on line 174.
ACK
Also doesn't look used?
used on line 193.
ACK
No need to put an else if the previous line returns.
done. yep, sorry I keep on making this mistake.
Just do emplace here.  There's no expectation of collisions in this structure, and in the unlikely event that it happens, destroying the old object is fine.
No, I didn't want to create new handler for same route. Currently single handler is shared by multiple connection for same route path.
This is not what we discussed.  One unix socket per connection, that way the error paths are greatly simplified.
Done
ok, done.
please write out the type here.  it's not obvious without looking at the definition of the function.
Done
we now had a handler per connection.  Can this ever happen?
No we don't have handler per connection. We have a handler per route path. I am worried about creating lot of buffers if someone try to run denial attack. But I need your input on this.
This is a safety issue.  You probably want to just lookup the struct in the db on the other side of this so that if the socket disconnects while this call is happening, we handle it right.
Done
Please remove the lambda.
Done
I much prefer we change the name of this class. `ObmcHandler` is essentially meaningless. `ConsoleHandler` would be much better. Maybe even `ConsoleSession`?
Done
The `inline` keyword is not needed when defining a function within the class definition.
Done

"std::array is a template class that encapsulate a statically-sized array, stored inside the object itself, which means that, if you instantiate the class on the stack, the array itself will be on the stack. Its size has to be known at compile time (it's passed as a template parameter), and it cannot grow or shrink."

I highly recommend using `std::vector` here instead. That will allocate space as needed on the heap.
nit, size_t please.
Done
Done
I don't think this needs to be a unique-ptr anymore?  Neither does the buffer.
Done
Please declare the input and output buffer above hostSocket, to avoid use after free destruction issues.
Done
Done

As we discussed, one socket to one session.  There's no need to put the sessions set into the connection object.

This can be a single reference to the Connection object.
Done
Done

for new instances of flat_map, please declare them using std::vector as a backing

boost::container::flat_map<std::string, ConsoleHandler, std::less<>, std::vector<std::pair<std::string, ConsoleHandler>>>;

It is exceptionally wordy, but allows:
1. Us to not pull in boost::vector (which doesn't optimize as well as std::vector)
2. lookups with keys that are string_view, without using an intermediate string.
Done
Done
Done
can this be renamed to "onClose".  I think that's more clear.
Done
Done
I've fixed all the outstanding comments, and changed it over to per-connection semantics.  Please review, and retest, and see if what I wrote works for you.

You've pushed another patchset on top of the one I pushed, and undone a significant number of fixes.  If you disagree with some of the fixes made in that patchset, lets have a discussion, but what was in patchset 10 can probably merge if it tests out ok for you.
oops, Sorry, I did not realize you are working on it.
Can you please re-push your changes on top of my patchset 12? I made lot of changes based on your review comments.

Done.  Feel free to use that as a new starting point for your changes.  The only thing I see that you changed functionally is the addition of a size check, which you're welcome to add back if you like, but as written, if this patchset tests correctly for you, it can merge.
ok, testing...
Done with testing.
